text:
1.2 Other crossref types
The same mechanism works for definitions, theorems, and similar divs.

Definition 1.1 A theorem-like div is a cross-referenceable named block in a Quarto document, as listed in the Quarto guide.


Example 1.2 This is the second example.

The attributes description and type are included as columns in the table of examples, so that information appears there for this example.

title: 2  Usage
text:
2.1 Project configuration
In the _quarto.yml file you need to include something like the following:
project:
  type: book
  pre-render: clean.ts
  post-render: concatenate.ts

filters:
  - crossref-listings

crossref_listings:
  - exm
  - def
The post-render script is required, as is the filters value. The crossref_listings entry is a list of theorem-like prefixes to be collected.

title: 2  Usage
text:
2.2 Custom fields
When you create a theorem-like div, you can give it extra attributes that Quarto ignores. These can then be referenced as columns in your listings table.

Example 2.1 Example 1.1 was created with the following code:
::::{#exm-example1 description="A fine example" type=foo}
## Good example
This is example 1.
::::

title: 2  Usage
text:
2.3 Creating cross-reference listings
The tables of cross references are created using the (listing)[https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-listings.html] mechanism of Quarto websites. All this extension does is to collect the relevant information in files in the _crossrefs subdirectory. You just include the one you want in the contents metadata of listing.

Example 2.2 To create the definition table below, the following was put into the metadata of this file:
listing:
  - id: Definitions
    contents: 
      - _crossrefs/def.yml
      - _crossrefs
    type: table
    fields: [title, link]
Then, at the place where the table is to appear, we put
:::{#Definitions}
:::
